summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York to FBI personnel, discussing organizational challenges with processing Epstein-related search warrant materials. The sender is trying to determine which materials on a hard drive are new versus previously received, highlighting a lack of tracking system for evidence.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Author of the email expressing frustration about the lack of organization in receiving and processing Epstein search warrant materials from the FBI.

events.title: Modified date of initial load files
events.description: 38 folders labeled 'loadFiles' through '37loadFiles' were modified, potentially containing previously received Epstein search warrant materials.

events.title: Modified date of new folder
events.description: A folder titled 'NYC024362' was modified, potentially containing new Epstein search warrant materials not previously received.

keyFacts: An Assistant U.S. Attorney is struggling to organize Epstein search warrant materials received from the FBI.
A hard drive contains 38 folders with a modified date of November 14, 2019, which may be duplicate materials.
A separate folder titled 'NYC024362' with a modified date of January 27, 2020, contains over 600,000 items and may be new evidence.
The email highlights a systemic problem: lack of a tracking system for which devices have been extracted and what materials correspond to each data transfer.
